results.title: Cesaria Evora
results.creator_credit: Eric Mulet, Anais Prosaic, Jean-Paul Guillemard, Gerard Pont, Gerard Lacroix, Morgane Production and La Sept-Arte
results.brief_description: Documentary on singer Cesaria Evora, born in the port town of Mindelo on the Cape Verde island of Sao Vicente - a former Portuguese colony off the north-west coast of Africa. Evora (born 1941) has brought the unique sounds of her birthplace, known as ‘morna’ - a slow, rhythmic song form that is a mix of blues, jazz and Portuguese folk - to world attention. Her magnificent voice and soulful singing is often accompanied by the acoustic sounds of guitar, cavaquinho, violin, accordion, and clarinet, in a expressive, lyrical style. Evora’s music conveys the struggles of her people and melancholy of their history. In this work Evora is interviewed in her home town and discusses her upbringing, early musical experiences, being a single mother, unexpected fame and remarkable life. Features interviews with family and friends and performances by Evora and other local musicians and singers in various cafes and bars. Internationally, Evora is known as the ‘barefoot diva’ for her propensity to appear on stage in bare feet. This DVD also includes a live concert of Evora’s from 1995.

results.title: Cesar's bark canoe
results.creator_credit: Bernard Gosselin, Paul Larose and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Building a canoe solely from the materials that the forest provides may become a lost art, even among the Indians whose traditional craft it is. In this film, Cesar Newashish, a sixty-seven-year-old Cree Indian of the Manowan Reserve north of Montreal, builds a canoe in th old way, using only birch bark, cedar splints, spruce roots and gum. With a sure hand he works methodically to fashion a craft unsurpassed in function or beauty of design. The film is without commentary but text frames appear on the screen in Cree, French and English. Award: New York

results.title: Cerveau gele
results.creator_credit: Pierre Moretti, Rene Jodoin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Claude Dubois sings out against the petrifying effect of growing cities. The images on the screen form and reform to reflect his sentiments. Music by Claude Dubois and photography by Claude Lapierre.

results.title: Ceremony
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Experimental Film and Television Fund
results.brief_description: Nearly completing his painting, the artist takes a walk outside, where his creativity manifests itself in the life around him. This experimental work captures the ritualistic spirituality of art and the art in the everyday. Paintings in the film are by Paul Mason.

results.title: Certaines Nouvelles = Certain News
results.brief_description:
Algeria, 1961. Laughter and music escape from an old sea-side house. Helene, Jean and Pierre try to remain oblivious to the reality surrounding them and their own insecurities. False illusion of peace and poisonned relations with friends are their lot while they attempt to spend one last summer as if nothing was happening. Award: Prix Jean Vigo 1979.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Meurisse ; director, Jacques Davila ; writers, Jacques Davila, Marie-France Bonin ; photography, Martial Thury.
Cast: Micheline Presle, Bernadette Lafont, Caroline Cellier, Frederic de Pasquale, Roger Hanin, Martine Sarcey, Gerard Lartigau.

results.title: Ceremonial ground painting: Aboriginal women artists from Papunya
results.creator_credit: Ian Stocks, Robyn Bondfield, Queensland Art Gallery and Kopano P/L Productions
results.brief_description: Eight women artists from the Papunya community were invited to Queensland Art Gallery to create a groundpainting that would enhance and extend the exhibition “The Inspired dream: life as art in Aboriginal Australia” This video documents the making of the painting, explanations of its symbolic meaning and the dancing ceremonies which are traditionally performed when the work is finished. The artists were Emma and Mali Nungurrayi, Topsy, Mary and Jeannie Napaltjarri, Mavis Napangati, Phylis Nakamarra and Mavis Nampitjinpa.

results.title: Centripetal Forces
results.credit_line:
Shaun Gladwell
Eight-channel video installation, variable duration
ACMI Collection
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, 8 channel video, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
“Centripetal Forces” is an eight-channel video installation commissioned for the exhibition “Shaun Gladwell: Stereo Sequences” in 2011.

“Centripetal Forces” (2011) is an elaboration of Gladwell’s interest in the dynamics and composition of the spinning figure, first seen in the single-channel “Pataphysical Man” (2005). “Centripetal Forces” takes the original image of the spinning figure and extends it into a series of comparative studies of gesture and movement by different performers. In the centre of each screen a performer enacts a basic spinning action over and over, each dancer representing a different language or subculture of movement.

Gladwell further pushes this internal paradox with a shift in perspective from the original work, changing the camera viewpoint from a front-on to an aerial view. The black and white negative images are projected on to screens suspended in the ceiling of the gallery, appearing as spinning astral bodies – a sparkling universe of whirling figures. There is a clear connection here to the “Planet & Stars Sequence” and to”‘Parallel Forces”. Are these bodies orbiting each other? Are they aware of their relationship to a wider planetary system? Are they stationary or are they turning on a still point?

The performers are training rather than performing; their focus is on repetition and rotation of movements. There is Emma Magenta, a capoeira dancer, whose roughly circular movements recall her performance in “Woolloomooloo Night” (2004). Her movements are more muscular and less centred than the tight, graceful, fluid pirouettes of Vivienne Wong, ballerina with the Australian Ballet. Anthony Lawang, a break dancer from Melbourne, performs a series of floor-based manoeuvres, transitioning from a top rock position to a backspin and a windmill, climaxing in a tight backspin, disrupting any sense of how his body is oriented spatially. Simon O’Brien, a world champion freestyle BMX rider, performs a series of highly technical spins in which the bike frame and his body are linked and twisted by concentric forces. In contrast to these athletic routines, Kathryn Puie spins her body on stilts. In the overhead shot foreshortening her body, we see her body constantly shifting and shuffling in order to remain upright. Gladwell himself performs on a skateboard, spinning continuously. Contemporary dancer Lee Wilson uses his body as the pivot point for a whirling bread tray that flies above and around him. Michelle Shimmy and Maddie Schonstein, professional pole dancers, perform an improvised routine together on a pole, experimenting with movements and pushing their bodies into unrehearsed positions.

results.title: Centre stage = Yuen Ling Yuk
results.creator_credit: Stanley Kwan, Willie Chan Chi Keung, Chui Siu Ming and Paragon Films
results.brief_description: Based on the real life of Chinese silent movie star Ruan Lingyu, ‘Centre Stage’ brings back to life the golden age of the ‘Hollywood of the East’, the Lienhau studios of Shanghai in the 1930s. Ruan (Maggie Cheung) is already an established star at age 20 when her world starts to collapse. First married to an immature, pleasure seeking play boy, she obtains a costly divorce in order to set-up house with Tang Chi Shan (Tony Leung Ka-fai), a producer at Lienhua who is also a married man. Tired of playing melodramatic characters, Ruan accepts a role in film directed by an up and coming director titled ‘New Woman’. The film is a vicious attack of the Chinese press whose tabloid style is pushing a woman to destruction. The press retaliates so violently that massive cuts are ordered to appease the anger of the opinion makers. This is the time Ruan’s ex-husband re-appears and threatens to expose her as an adulteress. Ruan’s star starts to spiral down. The film blends fact and fiction, documentary and narrative. Rare footage of the real Ruan’s performances are mixed with Cheung’s re-creations of Ruan’s lost films. In a clever twist of casting, the role of Ruan, originally intended for Anita Mui (Kwan’s star in ‘Rouge’), went to Maggie Cheung. Cheung was the same age as Ruan at the time of her suicide and had had many run-ins with the Hong Kong press. Kwan blends his narrative with documentary style footage of Cheung explaining how she researched the part and interviews with Chinese cinema veterans. The result is an interrogation on cinema itself. The film won several awards, including the Silver Bear for Best Actress at the 1992 Berlin Film Festival. Also stars Carina Lau, Waise Lee, Cecilia Yip. In Cantonese with English subtitles. The film is also known as ‘The Actress’, ‘The New China Woman’ in various English releases or ‘Ruan Ling-yu’ in Mandarin.

results.title: Centre court champions
results.creator_credit: Howard Rubie, British Petroleum and Cinesound
results.brief_description: Demonstrations of good play in tennis on a grass court and a hard court with comments by Harry Hopman. Emphasizes the need for good balance, skill in service, a great variety of strokes, and agile footwork; with some sequences in slow motion. Top Australian players are shown in action, including Tony Roche, John Newcombe, Owen Davidson and Lesley Turner. Concludes with the 1965 Australian Singles Finals, in black and white, with Roy Emerson and Fred Stolle.

results.title: Centralia
results.brief_description: Depicts scenic places around Alice Springs, Stanley’s Chasm, Hermannsburg, Ormiston Gorge, Glen Helen Gorge, Ayres Rock and The Olgas, and discusses the geology, history, living conditions and aboriginal mythology of the areas shown. Narrated by Ron Haddrick.
results.description: Depicts scenic places around Alice Springs, Stanley’s Chasm, Hermannsburg, Ormiston Gorge, Glen Helen Gorge, Ayres Rock and The Olgas, and discusses the geology, history, living conditions and aboriginal mythology of the areas shown. Narrated by Ron Haddrick.
